title: Event delegation finally clicked
content: Instead of adding event listeners to every child element, you can attach one listener to the parent and use event.target to figure out what was clicked. This works because of event bubbling and makes dynamic UIs much easier to manage.

title: Why Iâ€™m building projects without frameworks first
content: Using vanilla JS and Node forces me to actually understand what the browser and server are doing. Frameworks make things faster later, but right now fundamentals matter more than speed.

title: Idea: The Log Book
content: A simple app to store learning notes, thoughts, bugs, and ideas in one place. The goal isnâ€™t complexity â€” itâ€™s consistency. Something I can actually use every day.

title: Understanding Closures
content: Closures let a function remember variables from its outer scope even after that outer function has finished executing. Super useful for private variables and callbacks.

title: Why I love writing README files
content: Writing a good README forces me to clearly explain what my project does and how to use it. It's a mix of teaching and documenting â€” helps me think through my work.

title: Idea: Daily Coding Challenge
content: A mini-app that gives me a small coding challenge every day, tracks my streak, and shows how I improve over time. Could integrate tips and explanations for each problem.

title: Async/Await vs Promises
content: Async/await is syntactic sugar over promises. Makes code look synchronous but still non-blocking. Very handy for API calls or sequential async tasks.

title: Reflection on debugging mindset
content: Instead of immediately Googling errors, I try to reason through the problem first. This builds intuition and reduces dependency on stack overflow over time.

title: Idea: Logbook Tagging System
content: Allow users to tag notes with multiple labels for easier searching and grouping. Maybe even color-code tags for quick visual cues ðŸ«¡.
